etymology.description: 阳(陽) (yáng, "male; positive") + 具(具) (jù, "tool; implement") = implements of the male, referring to male genitals
etymology.interpretation: The term 阳具(陽具) (yángjù, "male genitals") combines 阳(陽) (yáng, "male; positive"), which is associated with masculinity and the yang principle in Chinese philosophy, with 具(具) (jù, "tool; implement") to denote what can be seen as the tools or implements of the male form.

examples.chinese: 这只动物的阳具异常明显(這隻動物的陽具異常明顯)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè zhī dòngwù de yángjù yìcháng míngxiǎn.
examples.english: The animal's male genitals are unusually conspicuous.

examples.chinese: 古希腊艺术常描绘阳具(古希臘藝術常描繪陽具)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔ Xīlà yìshù cháng miáohuì yángjù.
examples.english: Ancient Greek art often depicted male genitals.

examples.chinese: 在生物学中(在生物學中)，阳具是一个重要的研究对象(陽具是一個重要的研究對象)。
examples.pinyin: Zài shēngwùxué zhōng, yángjù shì yīgè zhòngyào de yánjiū duìxiàng.
examples.english: In biology, male genitals are an important subject of research.
